intro: Lophostachys montana, commonly known as the mountain dandelion, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid environments. Its bright yellow flowers bloom in the spring and are followed by fluffy seeds that are dispersed by the wind. Lophostachys montana is often found in open woodlands and grasslands, contributing to the ecological diversity of its habitat.
